text:
Happy New Year everyone !!

Inspired by the meetup in November, I put in a bit of effort which paid off in December, confirming what I already knew in my heart - you don't get 'owt for nowt - so my resolution for 2023 is to spend less time with my guitar & more time with Visual Studio :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:
Happy New Year everyone !!

Inspired by the meetup in November, I put in a bit of effort which paid off in December, confirming what I already knew in my heart - you don't get 'owt for nowt - so my resolution for 2023 is to spend less time with my guitar & more time with Visual Studio

text: A bit late, but for me my #1 goal is to be more efficient/faster at testing hypotheses.  I can't just run backtests for profit for every single thing, I need to figure out more proxy metrics. I do this for a hobby at the moment.

elements.text: A bit late, but for me my #1 goal is to be more efficient/faster at testing hypotheses.  I can't just run backtests for profit for every single thing, I need to figure out more proxy metrics. I do this for a hobby at the moment.

text: Also, participate at least once to a meetup (although it's been years since my last time in UK). I also suffer from the lack of sparring partner :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Also, participate at least once to a meetup (although it's been years since my last time in UK). I also suffer from the lack of sparring partner

text:
I reluctantly selected "broke-even" even though it's what most losing punters claim. My actual is > £5K and < £10K.
Kudos to whoever selected "lost over £50K" because admitting that is the first major step towards reversing the trend.

elements.text:
I reluctantly selected "broke-even" even though it's what most losing punters claim. My actual is > £5K and < £10K.
Kudos to whoever selected "lost over £50K" because admitting that is the first major step towards reversing the trend.

text: I dunno <@U016TGY3676> I would advise someone who lost £50k in a single year to pack it in - unless they are a high roller type and its recreational.

elements.text: I dunno
I would advise someone who lost £50k in a single year to pack it in - unless they are a high roller type and its recreational.

text: most successful bettors started with a negative pnl i would assume. The major difference between losing 1k and 50k is risk management. I think someone who lost 50k could still turn it around theoretically, but at the very least they should heavily rethink their approach to testing and scaling. Everybody writes a bad strategy sometimes, even the ones who selected >300k, but they wouldnt lose 50k on it.

text: I’m not sure they’re the best bands <@U016TGY3676> but wanted to replicate what they posted on the BA forum

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> I guess it's all relative. If it's first year on automation, then there's something drastically wrong. If it was -£50K out of £1M+ lifetime, then it's just a shit year. Although I'd still argue that -£50K over a year indicates something wrong. But to clarify my "kudos" comment, most punters would bury their head in the sand and say "broke even". Psychologically, admitting a loss is a major step forward, be it towards turning it around OR quitting altogether.
